title: An optical and electrically driven single-molecule Raman switch
description: The role of molecular junctions in nanoelectronics is most often associated with electronic transport; however, their precise characterization hinders their widespread development. Recently, most research has focused on investigating molecular junctions based on electronic characterization.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How a moth's taste preferences change with age
description: The larvae and adult forms of the cotton bollworm (Helicoverpa armigera) adopt different sugar-sensing systems to satisfy their requirements for food selection, according to new research.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Detecting gravitational waves with an interferometric seismometer array on the lunar near side
description: A team lead by Department of Astronomy, Beijing Normal University, recently proposed a promising plan to detect gravitational waves (GWs) by putting seismometers on the moon's surface. Their research is published in the journal Science China Physics, Mechanics & Astronomy.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study shows animals like crickets use the ground to amplify calls
description: When animals "sing" sitting on the ground—such as when crickets chirp—their volume and reach increase dramatically, by as much as ten-fold. This result from a study by Western researchers, published today in the journal PNAS, contradicts long-held beliefs in the field of animal communication, which presume the ground is a hindrance to sound transmission.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Education is key to curbing antimicrobial resistance in cats, study says
description: Better education for cat owners, more communication from veterinarians, increased drug choices and cheaper, rapid diagnostic tools can help improve antimicrobial use in cats, which has important implications for rising antimicrobial resistance in animals and humans, according to two new papers by Cornell researchers.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New date evidence for landslides reveals past Seattle fault earthquakes
description: New maps of more than 1,000 deep-seated landslides in the Puget Lowlands of Washington State provide evidence of the last major earthquake along the Seattle Fault about 1,100 years ago—and may also hold traces of older earthquakes along the fault.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Volcanic eruption: Scientists perform volcanic scenarios to develop response plan
description: What would happen if a volcano were to erupt tomorrow in New Mexico? How prepared as we as a society for an event like this to occur? When volcanic unrest occurs, both academic and government agencies need to have advanced fundamental understanding of the volcanic system with coordination before, during and after the event. This necessity has prompted the development of a response plan.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Research improves formable cellulose-based food packaging to replace single-use plastic
description: In a pilot-scale study to find alternative raw materials for rigid plastic packages, VTT Technical Research Center of Finland has obtained unprecedented maximum limits of its highly extensible formable cellulose-based webs used for rigid packaging applications. The results enable the manufacturing of a wide range of sustainable 3D packaging solutions that were previously unattainable.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: 3D printing precisely: Low-cost error compensation for fabrication of high-precision microstructures
description: In today's fast-paced technological landscape, the proverb "the bigger the better" was turned upside down and a race to make everything smaller has started. From miniature optical components to micro-scale medical devices, the quest for creating ever smaller yet more intricate structures has led to remarkable progress in a wide range of fields.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study shows what kind of salt we use on the roads in winter can make a difference for plants
description: Increased salinity in soils is a global problem caused, for example, by ions leaching into soils from ice-melting salts used on roads in winter or from seawater seepage in coastal areas.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Evaluating dual hydration of the oceanic lithosphere
description: A new study led by Dr. Jian Lin (Southern University of Science and Technology) and Dr. Fan Zhang (South China Sea Institute of Oceanology, Chinese Academy of Sciences) reexamines how the ocean's lithosphere operates.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New database unifies the information on damage to European forests over the last 60 years
description: The University of Córdoba is participating in the creation of the first database that harmonizes the recording of disturbances caused by insects and diseases in forests in eight European countries by combining remote sensing, satellite images and field data
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study finds that colostrum is key to saving beef calves from trouble
description: In a pair of recent studies, researchers examined risk factors that contribute to insufficient antibody transfer to newborn beef calves, as well as the subsequent negative health effects. They found that the mother's parity (in "heifers" or first-time cow moms vs. older cows) and the need for colostrum intervention were the risk factors most likely to result in insufficient antibody protection. Further, they found that calves with low or failed antibody transfer that do survive have increased medical treatment needs, higher mortality rates and lower body weights.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers propose an organic-solvent-free method for producing nanosized vaterite
description: Vaterite is one of the three forms of calcium carbonate, along with calcite and aragonite. Nanosized vaterite is valuable for various applications, such as drug delivery, cosmetics, and bone defect filling, owing to its biocompatibility, high porosity, solubility, and large specific surface area.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: UN report reveals trillions in hidden costs of agrifood systems
description: Hidden environmental, social and health costs of agrifood systems were as much as $12 trillion globally in 2020, according to new research from the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), based on analysis by Oxford's Dr. Steven Lord.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Workplace wellness policies could soften the effects of workaholism, study suggests
description: Employers should consider more ways to facilitate time off for the employees who are least likely to take it—workaholics. That's the conclusion of counseling experts who conducted a workaholism study published in The Career Development Quarterly.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Bleu Royal diamond rakes in nearly $44 mn at Geneva auction
description: An exceptionally rare blue diamond went under the hammer in Geneva Tuesday, selling for more than $40 million, making it one of the most expensive diamonds ever sold at auction, Christie's said.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How machine learning can support data assimilation for Earth system models
description: Data assimilation is the combination of the latest observations with a short-range forecast to obtain the best possible estimate of the current state of the Earth system. Machine learning can contribute to it by optimizing the use of satellite observations.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Governments should stop converting land use, says UN scientist
description: Governments need to stop allowing land to be converted in the face of rising global consumption, a leading UN scientist has warned, as data shows the world is off track to meet land degradation targets.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Report: Political violence threatens health of US democracy
description: Political violence is eroding the overall health of democracy in the United States, according to more than 100 global scholars surveyed for a new report.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New microfossils suggest earlier rise in complex life
description: Microfossils from Western Australia may capture a jump in the complexity of life that coincided with the rise of oxygen in Earth's atmosphere and oceans, according to an international team of scientists.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: The presidential election is one year out. Why predictions are more reliable than polls when picking a winner
description: In 2015, Northeastern University associate professor of political science Nick Beauchamp predicted that Donald Trump had a 25% chance of winning the next year's presidential election.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Cultivation of grass significantly reduces nitrogen leaching from cultivated peatlands: Study
description: Perennial grass cover significantly reduces nitrogen leaching from cultivated peatlands, according to a recent study published in Science of The Total Environment. In measurements of Ruukki NorPeat field, the least amount of nitrogen was leached from field blocks covered with grass and thin peat layer. The largest nitrogen leaching came from plots with thicker peat without plant cover or with barley in the spring and during the mild winter. Phosphorus and organic carbon leaching increased as peat thickness increased.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Top consultancy undermining climate change fight: whistleblowers
description: The world's top management consultancy McKinsey & Company is using its position as a key advisor to the UN's COP28 climate talks to push the interests of its big oil and gas clients, undermining efforts to end the use of the fossil fuels driving global warming, according to multiple sources and leaked documents.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Black women teaching science find ways for incorporating anti-racist practices
description: Whether teaching about the practices and systems that led to high rates of diabetes in Black communities or discussions about the Flint water crisis, Black female science teachers are finding ways to incorporate anti-racist teaching in their classrooms, according to a new study by science education researchers.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Gate induced room-temperature magnetic phase transition realized in van der Waals ferromagnet nanoflakes
description: By intercalating protons into van der Waals ferromagnet Cr1.2Te2 nanoflakes, a group of researchers successfully induced a room-temperature magnetic phase transition from ferromagnetism to antiferromagnetism.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Scientists develop open archive of plant images and related phenotypic traits
description: Plant images contain a wealth of information that reflects key phenotypic characteristics such as color, shape, growth, and health status of plants. High-throughput plant phenotypic collection technology has been widely applied in plant phenomics, generating numerous images and image-based traits (i-traits) data. These data serve as important resources for various agricultural applications, including germplasm screening, plant pests and disease identification, and agronomic traits mining.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Fungal hybrids study finds climate crisis could trigger outbreak of new and lethal infectious diseases
description: The climate emergency poses a major threat to human health. Rising temperatures and changes in ecosystem conditions, coupled with globalization and human action, such as the extensive use of fungicides and antibiotics in agriculture, can favor the emergence and spread of new species of hitherto underestimated potentially virulent pathogenic microorganisms, such as fungi.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Supermassive black holes shut down star formation during cosmic noon, says astronomer
description: Since it became operational almost two years ago, the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) has produced countless breathtaking images of the universe and enabled fresh insights into how it evolved.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope could finally tell us if primordial black holes exist
description: When the universe erupted into existence with the Big Bang, all of its matter was compressed into a tiny area. Cosmologists theorize that in some regions, subatomic matter may have been so tightly packed that matter collapsed into primordial black holes. If these primordial black holes exist, they're small, and they could be hiding among the population of free-floating planets.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: JWST detects carbon dioxide in a centaur for the first time
description: A study published Nov. 6 in The Planetary Science Journal examines how NASA's James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) has conducted a first-time detection of carbon dioxide in a centaur, this one designated 39P/Oterma. A centaur is a small planetary body that orbits between Jupiter and Neptune and frequently crosses the orbits of one or more of the gas giant planets within our solar system.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: This is a first: An exoplanet in a polar circumbinary disk surrounding two stars
description: We live in an age of exoplanet discovery. One thing we've learned is not to be surprised by the kinds of exoplanets we keep discovering. We've discovered planets where it might rain glass or even iron, planets that are the rocky core remnants of gas giants stripped of their atmospheres, and drifting rogue planets untethered to any star.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Silver reveals luxury tastes of Vikings and trade talents of ancient Greeks
description: Vikings, traditionally depicted as primitive bearded warriors, had a fondness for some of life's precious things. In Europe, hundreds of buried hoards of silver testify to its attraction for Vikings when they lived more than 1,000 years ago.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: A new kind of trade deal could help protect the world's tropical forests
description: Historically, trade liberalization has been bad news for the world's tropical forests. As wealthy nations' appetite for imported agricultural goods like beef and soy has exploded, deforestation in countries such as Brazil has surged.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Collaborative landscape design approach may improve resiliency, human well-being
description: A newly proposed landscape stewardship framework may lead to a more resilient and adaptable environment and improved quality of life for people. Called regenerative landscape design (RLD), the approach was recently developed by a multi-institution collaboration led by Penn State researchers to enhance sustainability and better address complex and interconnected environmental and social challenges, such as climate change, biodiversity loss and social inequality.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Warmer, wetter winters bring risks to river insects
description: Research by Cardiff University has shown that the warmer, wetter winters in the U.K. caused by climate change are likely to impact the stability of insect populations in streams.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study shows how having parents from two different African countries shapes identity
description: More than a third of migration in sub-Saharan Africa happens within the continent. This mixing of people means that some children have parents of different national origins. Yet not enough is known about the lives of these children: how they form their identity and what impact migration has on them.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Climate change hits indebted businesses hardest, new research suggests
description: Climate change poses the biggest risks to the most vulnerable people, and the same is true for businesses: Highly leveraged companies—those that have accumulated too much debt—are uniquely susceptible to climate shocks. That's what we found in a forthcoming study in The Review of Corporate Finance that analyzed data from more than 2,500 U.S. publicly listed companies over 16 years.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How global warming shakes the Earth: Seismic data show ocean waves gaining strength as the planet warms
description: As oceans waves rise and fall, they apply forces to the sea floor below and generate seismic waves. These seismic waves are so powerful and widespread that they show up as a steady thrum on seismographs, the same instruments used to monitor and study earthquakes.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How do we retain teachers? Supporting them to work together could help
description: Australia is in the grips of a teacher shortage "crisis" according to Education Minister Jason Clare.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Planet Earth III: How cookie cutter nature programming could fail to educate, inform audiences
description: Perhaps nothing embodies the BBC's values of inform, educate and entertain more than its nature documentaries. Planet Earth III is the latest in a proud tradition going back to the founding of the BBC Natural History Unit in 1957 and has everything devoted fans (myself included) expect.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How the pandemic permanently altered college towns
description: Universities are more than just halls of learning; they are vibrant ecosystems and often the beating heart of the towns they reside in. Their reach goes beyond academia and plays a significant role in shaping the local economies of North American college towns.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Trolling and doxxing: Graduate students sharing their research online speak out about hate
description: An increasingly volatile online environment is affecting our society, including members of the academic community and research they pursue.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers develop metal-enhanced fluorescence probes for influenza A virus detection
description: Recurring influenza epidemics, such as the one during World War I, the Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) outbreak in the 2010s, and the COVID-19 pandemic in recent years have made it evident that contagious viral respiratory diseases often make an appearance in the timeline of human history.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: A new trail to exoplanets: Team successfully detects ammonia isotopologues in atmosphere of cold brown dwarf
description: They reveal the origin of wine, the age of bones and fossils, and they serve as diagnostic tools in medicine. Isotopes and isotopologues—molecules that differ only in the composition of their isotopes—also play an increasingly important role in astronomy. For example, the ratio of carbon-12 (12C) to carbon-13 (13C) isotopes in the atmosphere of an exoplanet allows scientists to infer the distance at which the exoplanet orbits its central star.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Africa's dangerous air pollution levels are a global problem, says new research
description: A new report in Nature Geoscience has brought to light the challenge of air pollution levels in Africa and why international action is needed to combat it.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Data show Greenland's ice shelves have lost more than a third of their volume since 1978
description: The largest floating ice shelves in the polar ice sheet have lost more than a third of their volume since 1978. In a study published on Nov. 7 in Nature Communications, scientists from the CNRS, alongside their Danish and American colleagues, have established that most of this thinning is due to the rise in surrounding ocean temperatures, which causes the glaciers' floating extensions to melt.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Local adaptation may buffer some birds against climate change
description: North American song sparrows may be more resilient to climate change thanks to a remarkable adaptation: a stunning range of body sizes found throughout the bird's westernmost range.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Glimpses of the 'galactic zoo': The five new Euclid images
description: The first images from Europe's Euclid space telescope released Tuesday range from a well-known nebula to never-before-seen galaxies 10 billion light years away, illustrating its wide-lens view of the universe.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: 'Exceptional' floods hit northern France: authorities
description: Flooding has hit dozens of towns in northern France, leaving roads sometimes only passable in boats and dozens of schools closed, authorities said Tuesday.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New study sheds light on why some animals dive to the dark, deep sea
description: If you've ever witnessed a shark breach the water—whether in person or somewhere on the Internet—that fleeting but awe-inspiring moment is just a small fraction of the time it spends at the surface of the ocean. Most of the time sharks and other large marine predators are out of sight, begging the question—where do they go?
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Euclid mission releases its first images
description: The Euclid mission, which will investigate the mysteries of dark matter and dark energy, released its first five science images Tuesday, Nov. 7. The observatory, led by ESA (European Space Agency) with NASA contributions, is scheduled to begin regular science operations in early 2024.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers test lake water in Halifax for viruses to demonstrate enhanced detection device
description: When Emalie Hayes and her colleagues began exploring ways to test wastewater for the COVID-19 virus, little did she know that the simple, inexpensive device she developed would end up being used around the world to identify the presence of the pathogen in water systems.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers discover new method to inhibit cholera infection
description: Recent research investigates a novel strategy for inhibiting the spread and infection of Vibrio cholerae, the bacteria responsible for the disease, cholera.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Sustainable urban development: How do Finnish cities compare?
description: A University of Helsinki study published in npj Urban Sustainability explores the development of various sustainability indicators in Finnish cities from 2000 to 2018.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How looking beyond our borders would improve preparedness for extreme floods
description: Almost all extreme flooding across Europe could be anticipated by looking at previous major events in other similar parts of the continent, according to a new study.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: The cell's 'read–write' mechanism: Researchers uncover how instructions for gene expression are relayed
description: The "read–write" mechanism by which cells replicate and use chemical instructions for expressing genes has been uncovered by RIKEN researchers. The quality and quantity of gene expression correlates not only with instructions by transcription factors but also with chemical modifications to the various histone proteins, which provide a scaffold for DNA in the chromosomes.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: 'Hot' new form of microscopy examines materials using evanescent waves
description: Microscopes usually use backscattered radiation to create images, but a research group from the Institute of Industrial Science at the University of Tokyo is developing a new method to study materials using the faint light they emit, generated by heat
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: CT scan reveals 'neglected' dinosaur had super senses
description: A CT scan of an often-overlooked, plant-eating dinosaur's skull reveals that while it may not have been all that "brainy," it had a unique combination of traits associated with living animals that spend at least part of their time underground, including a super sense of smell and outstanding balance. The work is the first to link a specific sensory fingerprint with this behavior in extinct dinosaurs.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study shows historical volcanic eruptions triggered short-term global cooling
description: New international research led by the University of St Andrews reveals historical high latitude volcanic eruptions caused dramatic, but short-lived climate cooling.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How lab-made catalysts can help convert difficult greenhouse gases
description: Natural gas consists of light hydrocarbons such as methane and ethane. Such gases are more potent greenhouse gases than CO2, are constantly released into the atmosphere from natural gas wells, and are more difficult to store than, for example, their corresponding alcohols (methanol and ethanol, respectively).
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Plant biologists shed light on 144-year-old seedy mystery
description: In April 2021, four Michigan State University plant scientists met at an undisclosed area on campus to dig up a bottle containing seeds buried more than 144 years ago by MSU botanist William J. Beal.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Gently down the stream: Carbon's journey from land to sea and beyond
description: Rivers, streams, lakes, and reservoirs occupy just 1% of Earth's surface, but they provide a route for large amounts of terrestrial carbon to reach the ocean. Along the journey, carbon dioxide is also released into the atmosphere in a process known as evasion. But much about the land-to-ocean carbon cycle is not yet understood.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Designing a space bioprocessing system to produce recombinant proteins
description: Biomanufacturing based in space can improve the sustainability of deep space exploration.  Bioprocessing systems to advance biomanufacturing for space applications need to be developed. In a new report now published in npj Microgravity, Mathangi Soundararajan and a team of scientists in bioengineering and space biosciences at the NASA Ames Research Center, California, have developed commercial technologies to design space bioprocessing systems that supply a liquid amine carbon dioxide scrubber with recombinant active carbonic anhydrase. The design workflows encompassed a biomass of 1 L of Escherichia coli cultures using recombinant protein purification.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Research shows that photorespiration does not protect against fluctuating light conditions
description: Photosynthesis is one of the most important metabolic processes in nature: It is critical for plant growth and thus for the production of plant-based foods. In close cooperation with the Max Planck Institute of Molecular Plant Physiology (MPI-MP), a German-American research team headed by Heinrich Heine University Düsseldorf (HHU) has now investigated whether a specific metabolic pathway in photosynthesis that competes with carbon fixation has a protective function for plants.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Studies of geologic faulting on icy moons aid exploration of extraterrestrial watery worlds
description: On the surface of many of the icy moons in our solar system, scientists have documented strike-slip faults, those that occur when fault walls move past one another sideways, as is the case at the San Andreas fault in California. Two recently published studies led by University of Hawai'i at Mānoa Earth and space scientists document and reveal the mechanisms behind these geologic features on the largest moon of Saturn, Titan, and Jupiter's largest moon, Ganymede.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Widely accepted Weyl semimetal shown to be a magnetic semiconductor
description: Weyl semimetals are highly sought after by material scientists. First predicted in the early 2010s, they belong to the class of topological materials that owe their unique transport, optical and thermoelectric behavior to distinct geometric and topological features, rather than to their chemical composition. What sets Weyl semimetals apart is that their electrons behave as if they are massless due to the presence of nodes in the electronic band structure, leading to unusual and interesting properties.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Globular cluster NGC 6284 inspected by astronomers
description: Italian astronomers have used the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) to perform high-resolution optical observations of a poorly studied globular cluster known as NGC 6284. Results of the observational campaign, published October 26 on the pre-print server arXiv, shed more light on the properties and nature of this cluster.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Chinese scientists unravel cGNAT2 role in cyanobacteria
description: Cyanobacteria are a diverse group of gram-negative bacteria that conduct plant-like oxygenic photosynthesis and are thought to be the evolutionary ancestors of chloroplasts in higher plants. Lysine acetylation is an important regulatory posttranslational modification that controls photosynthesis and metabolic processes in cyanobacteria and plants.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Combined treatment using lipid nanoparticles shows promise against antibiotic resistant bacteria
description: A large Australian team led by Monash University has devised a new approach to killing antibiotic-resistant bacteria using lipid nanoparticles that target specific layers on the surface of the bacterial cell.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Teaching AI systems to use intuition to find new medicines
description: A combined team of biomedical researchers from Novartis Institutes for Biomedical Research and Microsoft Research AI4Science has made inroads into teaching AI systems how to find new medicines. In their study, reported in the journal Nature Communications, the group used feedback from chemists in the field to provide intuition guidelines for an AI model.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Deforestation across the 'Maritime Continent' is making El Niño-Southern Oscillation more unpredictable, finds study
description: El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) is a climate phenomenon occurring every 2–7 years in the tropical Pacific Ocean, associated with changes in air pressure east to west.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: After October festivities, Illinoisans smash thousands of pumpkins to divert them from landfills, cut methane
description: As people rush to get rid of their jack-o'-lanterns in favor of Thanksgiving decorations, thousands of ornamental pumpkins will likely end up in landfills.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: As first Vulcan flight nears, new space plane Dream Chaser preps for launch No. 2
description: The Sierra Space Dream Chaser looks like a mini space shuttle, and it's gearing up for its first trip to space atop United Launch Alliance's new Vulcan Centaur rocket in 2024.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: 'Biodiversity time machine' provides insights into a century of loss
description: Scientists have run the first proof of concept of their DNA 'time machine' to shed light on a century of environmental change in a freshwater lake—including warming temperatures and pollution, leading to the potentially irreversible loss of biodiversity.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Masks are back, construction banned and schools shut as toxic air engulfs New Delhi
description: A toxic blanket of grey smog hangs over New Delhi's monuments and high-rises. Schools have been ordered shut and construction banned. People are back to wearing masks.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Corporations fall short on implementing green agendas: report
description: Corporations are increasingly committed to green agendas, but a new report on Tuesday reveals that only one in 20 of over a thousand publicly listed companies have a detailed strategy for how they will reach their greenhouse gas targets.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
